metadata.title: nano-photocatalysts: Synthesis, characterization and photocatalytic degradation of methylene blue dye

sections.text:
lable at ScienceDirect
Contents lists avai
Journal of Molecular Structure
journal homepage: ht tp: / /www.elsevier .com/locate/molstruc
Spinel NixZn1 xFe2O4 (0.0 x 1.0) nano-photocatalysts: Synthesis, characterization and photocatalytic degradation of methylene blue dye
G. Padmapriya a, *, A. Manikandan a, **, V. Krishnasamy a, Saravana Kumar Jaganathan b, S. Arul Antony c
a Department of Chemistry, Bharath Institute of Higher Education and Research, Bharath University, Chennai 600 073, India b IJN-UTM Cardiovascular Engineering Centre, Faculty of Biosciences and Medical Engineering, Universiti Teknologi Malaysia, Skudai 81310, Johor, Malaysia c Post Graduate and Research Department of Chemistry, Presidency College, Chennai 600 005, India
a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 10 February 2016 Received in revised form 14 April 2016 Accepted 16 April 2016 Available online 20 April 2016
Keywords: Microwave combustion Nanoparticles Spinel ferrites Structural analysis Magnetic properties Photocatalysts
* Corresponding author. ** Corresponding author.
E-mail addresses: ppstminex@gmail.com (G. Pad com, manikandana.che@bharathuniv.ac.in (A. Manika
http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.molstruc.2016.04.049 0022-2860/© 2016 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
a b s t r a c t
Spinel NixZn1 xFe2O4 (x ¼ 0.0 to 1.0) nanoparticles were successfully synthesized by a simple microwave combustion method (MCM) using metal nitrates as raw materials and glycine as the fuel. The structural, morphological and opto-magnetic properties of the spinel NixZn1 xFe2O4 ferrites were determined by Xray diffraction (XRD), Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR), high resolution scanning electron microscopy (HR-SEM), energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) spectroscopy, high resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM), selected area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern, UVeVisible diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (DRS), photoluminescence (PL) spectroscopy and vibrating sample magnetometer (VSM). Powder XRD, and EDX analysis was confirmed the formation of pure phase of spinel ferrites. HR-SEM and HR-TEM analysis was confirmed the formation of sphere like-particle morphology of the samples with smaller agglomeration. VSM analysis clearly showed the superparamagnetic and ferromagnetic nature of the samples. The Ms value is 3.851 emu/g for undoped ZnFe2O4 sample and it increased with increase in Ni content. Photo-catalytic degradation (PCD) of methylene blue (MB) dye using the samples were carried out and observed good PCD results.
© 2016 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Recently, nanostructured spinel ferrite materials possess unique electro-magnetic, optical and catalytic properties with extensive range of applications in multidisciplinary areas [1e5]. Spinel ferrites are semiconductor materials with a general formula AB2O4 (A ¼ Mn2þ, Co2þ, Ni2þ, Zn2þ, etc.: B ¼ Fe3þ) exhibit excellent optomagnetic, electrical and catalytic properties. Among them spinel zinc ferrite (ZnFe2O4) is an essential material in the areas of gas sensor [4], catalyst [5], photo-catalyst [6] etc. It is already reported that ZnFe2O4 is a normal spinel structure with Zn2þ ions situated at the tetrahedral (A) sites, whereas Fe3þ ions at the octahedral (B) sites [2].
mapriya), mkavath15@gmail. ndan).
Moreover, metal cations such as Mn2þ, Ni2þ, Co2þ, Cu2þ, etc. were doped into the spinel ZnFe2O4 nanostructures, they improved the structural, morphological, magneto-optical and photocatalytic activity, due to their significantmorphology and higher surface area with smaller particle size. However, Ni-Zn ferrite has attracted a vast of interest, because of its promising electromagnetic properties such as high resistivity, high permeability, and low dielectric loss in high frequency device applications. Also used inmany areas such as biosensors, drug delivery, catalysts, pigments etc [7e10].
Various methods such as solvothermal, co-precipitation, hydrothermal, citrate precursor, solegel and polyol methods [11e17] etc. have been used for the preparation of Ni-Zn ferrite nanoparticles. However, the above said methods meets some weakness such as, high-energy consuming, need of complicated equipment, requirement of a strong base, higher processing temperature and also require rather long reaction time to complete the crystallization of final products [18]. Recently, microwave irradiation method has gained much importance for the preparation of such functional nano ferrites [19,20]. In this method, microwaves interacts the
reactant molecules at the molecular level leads to a homogeneous heating, which results in the formation of ferrite nanoparticles within few minutes and leads to a higher efficiency [19,20].
Nowadays, spinel type magnetic nanomaterials have been extensively used in interdisciplinary areas and environmental applications, because of their outstanding catalytic activity, chemical stability, non-toxicity, and also reusability without loss in its catalytic activity. Due to themagnetic nature, spinel type nanomaterials have been easily separable and reusable catalysts. Hankare et al. [21] reported spinel ZnFe2O4 nano-catalysts for the PCD of methyl red and thymol blue. Manikandan et al. reported spinel ferrites photo-catalysts prepared by microwave irradiation method for the photocatalytic degradation (PCD) of methylene blue (MB) and 4- chloro phenol (4-CP); they found that the photocatalytic activity is increased with decrease in the crystallite size. Also, they reported the catalytic oxidation of benzyl alcohol into benzaldehyde using spinel ferrite nano-catalysts and found that the catalytic activity is increased with increase in the dopant cations [22e25]. Chung et al. [26] reported the PCD of methylene blue using TiO2-NiFe2O4 and SiO2-NiFe2O4 prepared by spray pyrolysis method. Fu et al. [27] reported ZnFe2O4-graphene photocatalyst for the PCD of MB. Xiong et al. [28] reported CdS-MFe2O4 nanocomposites for the PCD of rhodamine B and MB under visible-light irradiation.
However, there is no literature is available for the degradation of methylene blue dye under visible-light irradiation using Ni-doped ZnFe2O4 nano-photocatalysts prepared by microwave irradiation method using glycine as the fuel. Therefore, we have synthesized spinel NixZn1 xFe2O4 (x ¼ 0.0, 0.2, 0.4, 0.6, 0.8 and 1.0) nanoparticles by microwave combustion method using glycine as the fuel. Also, spinel NixZn1 xFe2O4 nanoparticles is highly remarkable and attractive to study as photocatalysts for PCD of azo dyes such as methylene blue, methyl orange, blue rhodamine B, methyl red and thymol blue, etc.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials and methods
sections.text: All the chemicals used in this study were of analytical grade obtained from Merck, India and were used as received without further purification. Zinc nitrate (Zn(NO3)2$6H2O, 98%), ferric nitrate (Fe(NO3)3$9H2O, 98%) and nickel nitrate (Ni(NO3)2.6H2O) were used as precursors and glycine as a fuel for this method. The compositions were prepared with the addition of nickel by different molar ratios (NixZn1 xFe2O4 with x ¼ 0.0, 0.2, 0.4, 0.6, 0.8 and 1.0) to ZnFe2O4. For the preparation of pure and Ni-doped ZnFe2O4 using the microwave combustion technique, the precursor mixture in glycine was placed into a domestic microwave oven and exposed to the microwave energy in a 2.45 GHz multimode cavity at 850W for 10 min. After the completion of the reaction, the solid powder was obtained and then it was washed with ethanol and dried at 70 C for 1 h. The obtained powders were labeled as ZnFe2O4, Ni0.2Zn0.8Fe2O4, Ni0.4Zn0.6Fe2O4, Ni0.6Zn0.4Fe2O4, Ni0.8Zn0.2Fe2O4 and NiFe2O4 respectively and were used for further characterizations.

sections.heading: 2.2. Characterization techniques
sections.text:
The structural characterization of NixZn1 xFe2O4 (x ¼ 0.0, 0.2, 0.4, 0.6, 0.8 and 1.0) nanoparticles were performed using a Rigaku Ultima X-ray diffractometer equipped with Cu-Ka radiation (l ¼ 1.5418 Å). Structural refinements using the Rietveld method was carried out using PDXL program; both refined lattice parameters and crystallite size of the obtained ferrites were reported. The surface functional groups were analyzed by Perkin Elmer FT-IR
spectrometer. Morphological studies and energy dispersive X-ray analysis of NixZn1 xFe2O4 nanoparticles have been performed with a Jeol JSM6360 high resolution scanning electron microscope (HRSEM). The transmission electron micrographs were carried out by Philips-TEM (CM20). The surface area was derived from the N2 adsorptionedesorption isotherms using liquid nitrogen at 77 K by an automatic adsorption instrument (Quantachrome Corp. Nova1000 gas sorption analyzer). The UVeVisible diffuse reflectance spectrum (DRS) was recorded at room temperature using Cary100 UVeVisible spectrophotometer to estimate their band gap energy. The photoluminescence (PL) properties were recorded using Varian Cary Eclipse Fluorescence Spectrophotometer. Magnetic measurements were carried out at room temperature using a PMC MicroMag 3900 model vibrating sample magnetometer (VSM) equipped with 1 T magnet.

sections.heading: 2.3. Photocatalytic-degradation procedures
sections.text: All photochemical reactions under identical conditions were carried out in a self-designed photocatalytic reactor. This model consists of eight medium pressure mercury vapor lamps (8 W) set in parallel and emitting 365 nm wavelength. It has a reaction chamber with specially designed reflectors made of highly polished aluminium and built in cooling fan at the bottom and black cover to prevent UV leakage. It is provided with the magnetic stirrer at the center. Open borosilicate glass tube of 40 cm height and 12.6 mm diameter was used as a reaction vessel. The irradiation was carried out using only six parallel medium pressure mercury lamps. The solution was aerated continuously by a pump to provide oxygen and for the complete mixing of solution.

sections.heading: 3.1. HR-SEM analysis
sections.text: High resolution scanning electron microscopy (HR-SEM) was used to examine the surface morphology of the samples. Fig. 1a-c shows the HR-SEM micrographs of ZnFe2O4, Ni0.6Zn0.4Fe2O4, NiFe2O4 samples, respectively, exhibited uniform, almost spherical shaped particle like morphology with loosely agglomerated particles.

sections.heading: 3.2. HR-TEM analysis
sections.text: Fig. 2a-c shows the high resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM) images of ZnFe2O4, Ni0.6Zn0.4Fe2O4, NiFe2O4 samples, respectively, which consists of spherical shaped nanoparticles, which are good agreement and evidence of HR-SEM images. Also, the particle sizes of the sample ranging from 13 nm to 17 nm. Crystallite sizes, obtained from powder XRD analysis, are consistent with the sizes calculated fromHR-TEM. Fig. 2d shows the selected-area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern of Ni0.6Zn0.4Fe2O4 sample, which confirms well crystalline nature of the final product. Also, show spotty ring pattern without any additional diffraction spots, which characteristics the well crystallites of the spinel ferrite structure [29].

sections.heading: 3.3. EDX analysis
sections.text:
Fig. 3a-c shows the energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) results of ZnFe2O4, Ni0.6Zn0.4Fe2O4, NiFe2O4 samples, respectively. The peaks corresponding to the elements Fe, Zn and O were observed in undoped ZnFe2O4 (Fig. 3a) and the peaks of the elements Fe, Zn, Ni and O were observed in Ni0.6Zn0.4Fe2O4 sample (Fig. 3b). Also, the peaks corresponding to the elements Fe, Ni and O were observed in
undoped NiFe2O4 (Fig. 3c). A small peak is appeared at 2.1 KeV indicates the presence of gold (Au) peak, which has been used as a coating at the time of HR-SEM analysis for the better visibility of the surface morphology.

sections.heading: 3.4. Structural analysis
sections.text:
The structural analysis of spinel NixZn1 xFe2O4 samples was done by powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis. Fig. 4 shows the powder XRD patterns of spinel NixZn1 xFe2O4 (x ¼ 0.0, 0.2, 0.4, 0.6, 0.8 and 1.0) samples. The hkl planes of (220), (311), (222), (422), (400), (511), (440) and (533), confirm the formation of good crystallizationwith single phase of spinel structure (JCPDS No. 22-1012) [30]. There is no other peak, which indicates that the samples crystallize in single-phase cubic structure. The XRD peaks indicate well defined spinel phase that was developed during the combustion. However, a peak of a-Fe2O3 phase observed for the sample Ni0.4Zn0.6Fe2O4 at 2q ¼ 33.15 (Fig. 4, black ball) due to the partial oxidation of spinel Ni-Zn ferrites [30]. The intensity of main diffraction peak of cubic spinel ferrite at (311) planewas considered as a measure of its degree of crystallinity.
The average crystallite size (L) was calculated from the diffraction line-width of XRD pattern (calculated for the (311) peak), based on Scherrer's relation:
L ¼ 0:89l b cos q
where L is the crystallite size, l, the X-ray wavelength, q, the Bragg diffraction angle and b, the full width at half maximum (FWHM). The calculated average crystallite size of the samples is shown Table 1. It was found that the crystallite size of undoped ZnFe2O4 is 21.15 nm and it is decreased to 15.63 nm with increasing the Nidopant (Ni0.6Zn0.4Fe2O4) and further increasing the Ni-content (x ¼ 1.0), the crystallite size is increased to 18.56 nm (NiFe2O4).
Powder XRD data is fitted using the Rietveld refinement XRD analysis and the corresponding spectra is given in Fig. 5. Rietveld refinement XRD was designed to refine simultaneously both the lattice parameter and crystallite size and the observed values are listed in Table 1 (Fig. 6). From the results, it was observed that lattice parameter values decreased from 8.439 Å (ZnFe2O4) to 8.398 Å (NiFe2O4) with increase in the Ni-dopant, which is in good accordancewith the standard JCPDS value of 8.441 Å (JCPDS No. 22- 1012). It is mainly due to the replacement of larger ionic radius of Zn2þ (0.83 Å) ions in ZnFe2O4 spinel by smaller ionic radius of Ni2þ (0.74 Å) ions [31,32].

sections.heading: 3.5. FT-IR analysis
sections.text: The formation of functional groups was confirmed by Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy. Fig. 7 shows the FT-IR spectral analysis of spinel NixZn1 xFe2O4 (x ¼ 0.0, 0.2, 0.4, 0.6, 0.8 and 1.0) nanoparticles. Two major wide-ranging metal-oxygen (M O) peaks are seen in the FT-IR spectra in the range of 900 to 450 cm 1, which confirmed the spinel ferrites. The maximum one frequently observed in the range 600e500 cm 1 match to fundamental stretching vibrations of the metal at the A-site, Mtetra 4 O, while the lowest peak, usually observed in the range 450e400 cm 1, is assigned to B-site metal stretching, Mocta 4 O [33,34]. The broad peaks observed at ~3450 and ~1630 cm 1 demonstrate the occurrence of adsorbedwater on the surface of the spinel ferrite materials.

sections.heading: 3.6. VSM analysis
sections.text:
The magnetic properties of the samples were investigated by vibrating sample magnetometer (VSM) at room temperature. Fig. 8 shows the magnetic hysteresis (M H) loops of measurements of spinel NixZn1 xFe2O4 (x ¼ 0.0, 0.2, 0.4, 0.6, 0.8 and 1.0) samples and the observed values such saturation magnetization (Ms), remanent magnetization (Mr) and coercivity (Hc) are reported in Table 1 (Fig. 9). The main advantage of magnetically responsive photocatalysts can be recovered and recycled readily than the conventional catalysts [35]. The prepared spinel NixZn1 xFe2O4 nanophotocatalysts can be separated from water by the appeal of outside magnetic field. Besides, the prepared photocatalyst can be re-dispersed intowater after eliminating the applied magnetic field
and reused. When non-magnetic nature of Zn2þ in ZnFe2O4 is substituted by magnetic nature of Ni2þ ions, there is a drastic change in magnetic properties [36e38]. TheMs value of undoped ZnFe2O4 is 3.851 emu/ g and the values are increased up to 37.93 emu/g with increasing the Ni-dopant and the sample NiFe2O4 shows higher value. From the results, it is clearly understood that the composition and cation distributions are highly influenced the magnetic properties [39e43]. Spinel ZnFe2O4 is a soft magnetic material. The M H curves demonstrate a typical superparamagnetic behavior of ZnFe2O4, Ni0.2Zn0.8Fe2O4 and Ni0.4Zn0.6Fe2O4 nanoparticles with lower Mr and Hc values, which is confirmed by the non saturation, observed in M H loop and the absence of the hysteresis.
However, the samples Ni0.6Zn0.4Fe2O4, Ni0.8Zn0.2Fe2O4 and NiFe2O4 show a hysteresis, thus indicating the ferromagnetism, due to the increase in the magnetic nature of the Ni2þ concentration in ZnFe2O4 lattice. The change in the value of Ms is most probably due to the difference in the cation distribution at the tetrahedral (A) and octahedral (B) sites. It is reported that Zn2þ ions prefer to the occupy A-sites; Ni2þ ions prefer to occupy the B- sites, while Fe3þ ions partially occupy the A- and B- sites [44e48]. Moreover, the very low values of Hc and Mr, indicate that they are also soft magnets.

sections.heading: 3.7. Photocatalytic activity
sections.text:
It is usually known that particle size, surface area, morphology, nature and concentrations of dopant metal ions are considerable factors that manipulate their catalytic activity. Jia et al. [49] reported that the photocatalytic activity of spinel ZnFe2O4
nanoparticles obviously relies on surface properties and surface defects. Manikandan et al. [50] reported that ZnFe2O4 photocatalysts for the photocatalytic degradation (PCD) of 4-CP and their degradation efficiency depends on their particle size and morphology. Thus, the authors compared undoped and Ni-doped ZnFe2O4 nanoparticles for the PCD of MB dye and a sequence of experiments were carried out under UVeVis light at 365 nm in wavelength.

sections.heading: 3.7.1. Effects of Ni doping on the photocatalytic activity of ZnFe2O4 nanoparticles
sections.text:
The control of Ni doping on spinel ZnFe2O4 nanoparticles on the PCD of MB was evaluated (Fig. 10). The PCD efficiency of MB is very low when used undoped ZnFe2O4 nanocatalyst, and it was enhanced with increasing the Ni dopant and showed a maximum PCD activity of the sample Ni0.6Mn0.4Fe2O4 (x ¼ 0.6), which may be due to the higher surface area volume ratio and smaller particle size of Ni0.6Zn0.4Fe2O4 nanoparticles. Nevertheless, excessive amounts of Ni-dopant (x ¼ 0.8 and 1.0) in spinel ZnFe2O4 lattice can retard the photocatalytic activity, due to the excess amounts of Ni-dopants
deposited on the surface of ZnFe2O4, which results in the decrease of PCD efficiency. Moreover, the sample Ni0.6Zn0.4Fe2O4 nanoparticles showmaximum photocatalytic activity of MB degradation in an obvious increase in Ni-dopant (Fig. 11). However, in our present study confirms that the PCD efficiency of spinel ZnFe2O4 sample was improved by the addition of Ni-content.

sections.heading: 3.7.2. Effect of surface area on the photocatalytic activity of NixZn1 xFe2O4 nanoparticles
sections.text:
The materials have higher specific surface area, which encouraging effect on the catalytic activity of photo-catalysts. It is well known that, when the particle size decreased, the surface area increased significantly, and the particles dispersion amounts are increased in solution, which enhanced the photon absorbance, which leads to recover their catalytic activity. Surface areas of ZnFe2O4, Ni0.2Zn0.8Fe2O4, Ni0.4Zn0.6Fe2O4, Ni0.6Zn0.4Fe2O4, Ni0.8Zn0.2Fe2O4 and NiFe2O4 nanoparticles are 27.65, 29.48, 32.95, 36.63, 35.72 and 34.54 m2/g, respectively. The surface area is improved with increasing Ni content upto x ¼ 0.6 and the sample Ni0.6Zn0.4Fe2O4 have higher surface area (36.63 m2/g) than other
samples (Table 1). Moreover, the decrease of particle size increased the surface area and the results are good agreement with the average crystallite size calculated by powder XRD analysis. It is understood that increase of surface area, the number of active sites in catalytic surface, which enhanced the photocatalytic activity
(Fig. 10). However, the higher surface area of spinel Ni0.6Zn0.4Fe2O4 nanoparticles showed better photocatalytic activity than other samples [51,52].

sections.heading: 3.7.3. Effect of the catalyst dosage on the photocatalytic degradation of methylene blue dye
sections.text: A blank experiment without any catalyst was carried out to examine the amount of degradation (Photolysis) efficiency of MB, and there is no evidence of PCD of MB in aqueous solution was observed. When, Ni0.6Zn0.4Fe2O4 nanocatalyst present in aqueous solution, PCD of MB was observed under irradiation of UV light. Also, the PCD efficiency of MB was found to be increased with increasing in the amount of Ni0.6Zn0.4Fe2O4 nanocatalyst up to 30 mg/100 mL. However, further increase of amount of Ni0.6Zn0.4Fe2O4 catalyst showed negative effect (Fig. 12). When increase the amount of nano-catalyst increased the active sites on the catalyst surface, which in twist increased the amount of _OH (hydroxyl) and O2 (superoxide) radicals, and degrade the MB dye. Also, the addition of excess amount of catalyst beyond the optimum may answer the agglomeration of catalyst particles and formed turbidity, which result lower photon absorption, and thereby, PCD efficiency was decreased [53,54].

sections.text:

photocatalytic experiments were carried out at different pH ranging from 3 to 9 for MB dye concentration (20 ppm) and catalyst loading (30 mg/100 mL). Fig. 13 shows the photocatalytic activity of Ni doped ZnFe2O4 nanoparticles with different pHs. The maximum 94% PCD efficiency was obtained at pH 3 within 90 min under UVlight [55]. The adsorption and degradation of MB dye depending on the surface charge of the catalyst and pH are effective parameters that affect the surface state [56]. The maximum PCD efficiency shows at pH 3, due to electrostatic desirability among anionic dye (MB) and positively charged surface (nano-catalyst). However, increasing the level of pH at greater than 7, the surface of nanocatalyst has become negatively charged that leads to electrostatic revulsion between MB and catalyst, which retards the PCD efficiency [57,58].

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
In summary, spinel NixZn1 xFe2O4 (x ¼ 0.0, 0.2, 0.4, 0.6, 0.8 and 1.0) nanoparticles were successfully prepared by a facile microwave irradiation method using glycine as a fuel. Powder XRD, Rietveld

Fig. 11. UVeVisible absorption spectra of PCD of MB (experimental conditions: k ¼ 365 nm, MB ¼ 200 mg/L, photocatalyst ¼ 30 mg/100 mL).
refinement XRD, FT-IR, SAED and EDX analysis were confirmed the formation of spinel phase ZnFe2O4 powders without any other secondary phase formation with well crystallized products. The average crystallite sizes of the samples are in the range of 16e22 nm in size, which was calculated by Debye-Scherrer formula. HR-SEM and HR-TEM images showed the particle-like morphology of the samples with slightly agglomeration. VSM technique showed that the Ms values of the undoped ZnFe2O4 sample is 3.851 emu/g, and it is increased with increasing Ni content. At lower Ni concentration (x ¼ 0.0, 0.2 and 0.4), the samples showed a superparamagnetic behavior, whereas at higher concentration (x ¼ 0.6, 0.8 and 1.0), they showed ferromagnetic behavior. In this present study, enhanced photocatalytic activity of NixZn1 xFe2O4 spinel nanocatalysts was observedwith the addition of Ni. PCD of MB azo dye was carried out and better results were observed than the reported results.

The adsorption and degradation of MB dye depending on the surface charge of the catalyst and pH are effective parameters that affect the surface state [56].

However, increasing the level of pH at greater than 7, the surface of nanocatalyst has become negatively charged that leads to electrostatic revulsion between MB and catalyst, which retards the PCD efficiency [57,58].

However, increasing the level of pH at greater than 7, the surface of nanocatalyst has become negatively charged that leads to electrostatic revulsion between MB and catalyst, which retards the PCD efficiency [57,58].

metadata.abstractText: Spinel NixZn1 xFe2O4 (x 1⁄4 0.0 to 1.0) nanoparticles were successfully synthesized by a simple microwave combustion method (MCM) using metal nitrates as raw materials and glycine as the fuel. The structural, morphological and opto-magnetic properties of the spinel NixZn1 xFe2O4 ferrites were determined by Xray diffraction (XRD), Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR), high resolution scanning electron microscopy (HR-SEM), energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) spectroscopy, high resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM), selected area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern, UVeVisible diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (DRS), photoluminescence (PL) spectroscopy and vibrating sample magnetometer (VSM). Powder XRD, and EDX analysis was confirmed the formation of pure phase of spinel ferrites. HR-SEM and HR-TEM analysis was confirmed the formation of sphere like-particle morphology of the samples with smaller agglomeration. VSM analysis clearly showed the superparamagnetic and ferromagnetic nature of the samples. The Ms value is 3.851 emu/g for undoped ZnFe2O4 sample and it increased with increase in Ni content. Photo-catalytic degradation (PCD) of methylene blue (MB) dye using the samples were carried out and observed good PCD results. © 2016 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
metadata.creator: Elsevier
